course_title: Professional Engineering and the Business Environment: Global Practice

learning_outcomes.description: Work effectively in diverse teams to deliver feasibility study reports and project pitch for an engineering project.
Develop engineering project scopes that align with project goals and stakeholder expectations.
Critically analyse and articulate the ethical responsibilities of engineers, specifically focusing on their duty to investors, clients, stakeholders, society, and future generations.
Evaluate engineering project risks associated with finance, logistics, policy, and other factors.
Identify key stakeholders for an engineering project.
Develop engagement plans to communicate effectively with diverse stakeholders of engineering projects from a global perspective.
Apply a suitable sustainable framework to an engineering project in a global context.
Evaluate and analyse economical feasibility and investment options, taking into consideration the costs, benefits, and sustainability of engineering project proposals.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1 evaluates each student’s professionalism demonstrated through consistent participation, preparation, and constructive teamwork across the semester.

Weekly workshops include structured activities that support the development of sequence reports and the final report, including briefings, Q&A sessions, progress reviews, and targeted feedback from the teaching team and invited faculty.

Students are expected to engage professionally by:

  • attending and participating actively in workshop activities and team progress discussions;
  • demonstrating preparation and contribution to team tasks and deliverables;
  • communicating respectfully and constructively with peers and staff;
  • responding appropriately to feedback and managing team processes (e.g., planning, document control, meeting discipline, and conflict resolution).

A required component of this assessment is the development and use of a Team Charter, which should be completed using the provided template. The Team Charter outlines agreed-upon roles, objectives, communication processes, document management procedures, and conflict resolution approaches. Students are expected to utilise the charter throughout the semester to support effective team operations and the delivery of project work.

Professionalism is assessed individually based on observed engagement and conduct during workshops and scheduled team check-ins, as well as evidence of contribution to team processes (including use of the Team Charter). Where required, staff may ask students to explain or justify elements of their team processes during workshop interactions.

Please refer to Blackboard for detailed marking criteria.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.assessment_title: Viva Voce Interview: Individual Demonstration of Understanding (Hurdle Assessment)
assessments.due_date:
11/05/2026 - 29/05/2026

The schedule for Viva Voce Interviews will be provided two weeks in advance.
assessments.task_description:
This assessment evaluates each student’s individual understanding of the project, independent of written team submissions.

Each student will participate in a structured viva voce (oral) interview conducted by a member of the teaching team during Weeks 11–13. The interview assesses the student’s ability to explain, justify, and critically reflect on the financial, sustainability, and risk aspects of their team’s project, as well as their individual contribution.

During the interview, students will be asked targeted questions relating to:

  • the financial analysis undertaken (including key assumptions, discounted cash flow logic, and interpretation of results);
  • sustainability considerations, stakeholder impacts, and ethical dimensions relevant to the project context;
  • risk identification, mitigation strategies, and sensitivity to uncertainty;
  • the student’s specific role and contribution within the team.

The interview is designed to verify that students can demonstrate genuine comprehension, professional judgement, and applied reasoning, rather than reproducing prepared or generated material. Students are expected to articulate concepts clearly, respond to follow-up questions, and adapt explanations to new or hypothetical scenarios posed during the interview.

This assessment is an individually secure assessment and includes a course hurdle requirement. Students must demonstrate a satisfactory level of individual understanding to pass the course, regardless of performance in team-based written assessments.

Please refer to Blackboard for detailed marking criteria.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 3 consists of a sequence of three project reports prepared by student teams. The sequence mirrors an authentic project development cycle, culminating in an integrated Final Investment Decision.

Report 1 (Week 5; 10%) (LOs 2, 4, 8) focuses on scoping early-stage projects and conducting financial evaluations. Teams develop and justify a discounted cash flow (DCF) analysis, including key assumptions, baseline/counterfactual framing, and comparison of project options where applicable.

Report 2 (Week 9; 20%) (LOs 3, 4, 5, 6, 7) extends the project by incorporating sustainability, stakeholder engagement, ethics, and project risk. Teams identify material impacts, propose mitigation and engagement strategies, and update project conclusions as appropriate.

Final Report (Week 15 / exam period; 30%) (LOs 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8) integrates the work from Reports 1 and 2, incorporating feedback from the teaching team and insights gained from the oral presentation process. The Final Report must present a coherent, evidence-based recommendation and a Final Investment Decision, supported by transparent assumptions and analysis.

Detailed requirements, submission format, and marking criteria are provided on Blackboard.

Use of AI/MT tools: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Workshop sessions

Workshops are interactive, facilitated sessions that replace tutorials. They combine short briefings with guided activities where students apply course concepts to their project context, work in teams on staged deliverables, and receive formative feedback from the teaching team. Workshops also include structured peer review, progress checkpoints, and time for consultation to support professional communication, stakeholder thinking, risk analysis, and sustainability integration in the project proposal.
